items.title: Ukraine secures pledge for security guarantees from European allies
items.description: At a key meeting in Paris, officials from Europe, Canada, the US and NATO said they would provide Kyiv's frontline forces with equipment and training, and back them up with air, land and sea support to deter any future Russian attack.

items.title: Australians trapped on Yemeni island after flare-up between Saudis and UAE
items.description: Australians are among hundreds of tourists scrambling to leave a remote Yemeni island, as a crisis on the mainland between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates causes travel chaos.

items.title: 'High volume' response after application for QVB windows to be made clear
items.description: Dozens of people have expressed opposition against a proposal to remove some of Queen Victoria Building's iconic coloured glass windows, after a development application stated they were not "fit for purpose in the eyes of global retail brands".

items.title: Colombia's Petro vows armed resistance after Trump threats

featured_image.name: U.S. slaps sanctions on Colombia President Petro over drug ... - NPR

items.description:
Colombian President Gustavo Petro issued a stark warning to the United States on Monday, declaring he would take up arms to defend his nation's sovereignty after President Donald Trump accused him of cocaine trafficking and threatened military intervention[1][2][3][4][5].

"I swore not to touch a weapon again since the 1989 Peace Pact, but for the Homeland I will take up arms again," Petro wrote on X, referring to his past as a member of the M-19 urban guerrilla group[2][5]. The former rebel fighter, who became Colombia's first leftist president in 2022, warned that any attempt to detain him would "unleash the popular jaguar" of the Colombian people[6][2][5].

items.title: Nvidia, AMD and Intel unveil AI chip platforms at CES

featured_image.name: Nvidia launches Vera Rubin, its next major AI platform, at CES 2026

items.description:
The world's leading chipmakers converged on Las Vegas this week to unveil their latest artificial intelligence computing platforms at CES 2026, with Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang declaring the arrival of "physical AI"—artificial intelligence that can understand and act in the real world[1][2][3].

Nvidia announced its Vera Rubin platform, a six-chip AI supercomputer now in full production and expected to ship in the second half of 2026[2][4][5]. The platform claims to deliver five times more AI training performance than its Blackwell predecessor while reducing inference token costs by tenfold[6][7]. Huang also introduced Alpamayo, an open-source autonomous driving AI model trained on 1,700 hours of driving data, which Mercedes-Benz will integrate into its upcoming CLA model[3][8][9].

AMD, not to be outdone, showcased its massive Helios rack-scale platform at CEO Lisa Su's keynote. The system weighs 7,000 pounds—equivalent to two compact cars—and houses 72 MI455X GPUs delivering up to 2.9 exaflops of AI inference performance[10][11][12]. The company also unveiled its Ryzen AI 400 series processors for laptops, featuring up to 60 TOPS of AI computing power and set to launch in the first quarter of 2026[10][13][14].

Intel countered with its Core Ultra Series 3 processors, branded Panther Lake, marking the first AI PC platform built on the company's 18A process technology and manufactured in the United States[15][16][17]. The chips will power over 200 PC designs from global partners, with consumer laptops available starting January 27[15][16]. Intel claims up to 180 platform TOPS and promises more than 50 percent faster CPU performance compared to previous generations[16][18].

items.title: Israel and Syria establish intelligence hotline under U.S. supervision

featured_image.name: Scoop: Israel-Syria talks planned in Paris with U.S. mediating

items.description:
Israel, Syria, and the United States announced Tuesday they have established a joint "fusion mechanism" for intelligence sharing and diplomatic coordination, marking a rare moment of formal cooperation between the longtime adversaries. The agreement, reached following the fifth round of U.S.-mediated talks in Paris, also includes plans to expand discussions into civilian areas such as energy, medicine, and agriculture[1][2][3][4].

The mechanism will function as a standing communication channel supervised by the United States to handle security exchanges, military de-escalation, and commercial opportunities between Jerusalem and Damascus, according to a statement[1][3][4]. U.S. officials pledged the system will "address disputes promptly" to prevent misunderstandings[1][4].

items.title: Iran offers $7 stipend amid protests over economic crisis

featured_image.name: Daily Life In Tehran Following The Latest Unrest In Iran

items.description:
Iran's government announced Monday it will distribute a monthly payment of approximately $7 to citizens in an attempt to quell nationwide protests that have left at least 35 people dead and sparked warnings from President Donald Trump.

Government spokesperson Fatemeh Mohajerani said the payments, worth one million tomans, would begin January 10 and aim to "preserve households' purchasing power, curb inflation, and ensure food security"[1][2]. The stipend represents a shift from $10 billion in annual import subsidies toward direct cash assistance, though the amount can buy only about 100 eggs, one kilogram of red meat, or several kilograms of rice at current prices[3][4].

items.title: Machete ambush after teenagers lured to park in Melbourne's west
items.description: Police are seeking help from the public to identify a group of teenagers wanted over what detectives have described as an ambush and machete attack in Caroline Springs, in Melbourne's west, last week.

items.title: Live: Trump plans to meet with US oil bosses at the White House
items.description: US President Donald Trump says he plans to meet with American oil companies. Follow live.

items.title: A missing mother, the desolate desert and a $500k reward
items.description: Angie Fuller has been missing for three years. Police are offering an equal record reward for information into what they believe is a suspected outback murder.

items.title: Day-by-day guide to most severe southern Australia heatwave in years
items.description: Southern Australia will collectively bake this week through the most intense spell of heat in years as temperatures soar up to 15 degrees Celsius above the mid-summer average.

items.title: Israel opens bidding for West Bank settlement to split territory

featured_image.name: Israel's Smotrich launches settlement plan to 'bury' idea of Palestinian state

items.description:
Israel has published a government tender seeking bids from developers to construct a settlement project near Jerusalem that would effectively divide the West Bank into northern and southern sections, marking the final step before construction begins on the long-frozen initiative.

The tender, posted on Israel's Land Authority website, calls for proposals to develop 3,401 housing units in the E1 area, an open tract of land east of Jerusalem[1][2][3]. The anti-settlement monitoring group Peace Now first reported the tender. Yoni Mizrahi, who runs the group's settlement watch division, said initial work could begin within the month[1][2][4].

The move follows Israel's final approval of the E1 project in August 2025, when the Higher Planning Council validated plans after rejecting all objections[5][6]. Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich, a far-right politician who oversees settlement policy, has championed the project. "The Palestinian state is being erased from the table not with slogans but with actions," he said when Israel gave final approval to the plan in August[3][7]. "Every settlement, every neighborhood, every housing unit is another nail in the coffin of this dangerous idea."

items.title: US pledges to back European force in Ukraine if Russia attacks

featured_image.name: Zelensky Turns to Europe After Talks With U.S. Officials

items.description:
The United States has pledged to support a European-led multinational force in Ukraine and lead ceasefire monitoring efforts under binding security commitments finalized at a Paris summit Tuesday, marking a significant shift in Western policy toward preventing future Russian aggression.

Draft statements from the gathering of the "Coalition of the Willing" indicate Washington will head a "continuous, reliable ceasefire monitoring system" with international participation following any peace agreement[1][2][3][4]. The US will also provide intelligence and logistics support to European forces deployed in Ukraine and commit to backing them "in case of attack" by Russia[1][2][3].

French President Emmanuel Macron is hosting representatives from 35 countries, including 27 heads of state, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, and US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, at the Élysée Palace[5][6][7]. The meeting aims to finalize contributions to security guarantees that Ukraine requires to deter further Russian aggression after nearly four years of war.

items.title: Trump's intervention in Venezuela is beyond comparison
items.description: The global shock caused by the Trump administration's interventions in Venezuela sent analysts scurrying for historic comparisons, but nothing really compares to what happened at the weekend.

items.title: White House refuses to rule out force in Greenland push

featured_image.name: Stephen Miller Asserts U.S. Has Right to Take Greenland

items.description:
White House Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller asserted Monday that Greenland should become part of the United States, questioning Denmark's sovereignty over the Arctic territory and refusing to rule out the use of military force to acquire it[1][2]. The statements, made during a CNN interview, triggered sharp rebukes from European leaders who warned that such action would threaten the NATO alliance and upside decades of post-World War II security cooperation[3][4].

"Nobody is going to fight the United States militarily over the future of Greenland," Miller said when pressed repeatedly about whether Washington would rule out military intervention[5][6]. He challenged Denmark's territorial claims, asking "by what right does Denmark assert control over Greenland?"[7][2]

The comments came days after a provocative social media post by Miller's wife, Katie Miller, who shared an image Saturday of Greenland covered in the American flag with the caption "SOON"[8][9]. The post followed closely on the heels of a U.S. military operation in Venezuela that captured President Nicolás Maduro, raising international concerns about the Trump administration's willingness to use force against sovereign nations.

items.title: China bans dual-use exports to Japanese military

featured_image.name: China Bans Exports of Dual-Use Items to Japan Military Users ...

items.description:
China announced on Tuesday an immediate ban on all exports of dual-use items to Japanese military end-users, marking the latest escalation in a diplomatic crisis between Asia's two largest economies that has deepened since November[1][2][3].

The ban, issued by China's Ministry of Commerce, prohibits the export of goods with both civilian and military applications to any Japanese military users or for purposes that could enhance Japan's defense capabilities[1][2][3]. The ministry warned that organizations or individuals from any country that violate the restrictions will face legal consequences[4][5][3].

Dual-use items encompass a wide range of technologies and materials including semiconductors, drones, chemicals, laser systems, satellite communication equipment, and advanced computing devices—products that serve commercial purposes but can also be adapted for military applications[6][7][8].

items.title: European leaders rally behind Greenland amid threats of Trump takeover
items.description: The US president and his officials are continuing to push for an American takeover of the Danish territory in the wake of their successful Venezuela operation, saying the island is needed for national security.

items.title: Japanese teams advance quantum computing with error correction breakthrough

featured_image.name: IBM and RIKEN Unveil First IBM Quantum System Two Outside of ...

items.description:
Japanese research teams are making parallel strides in quantum computing, with scientists at Institute of Science Tokyo achieving near-theoretical performance in error correction while RIKEN develops software to merge quantum computers with supercomputers.

A team led by Associate Professor Kenta Kasai at Institute of Science Tokyo has developed quantum error-correction codes that approach the theoretical limit known as the hashing bound, according to research published in npj Quantum Information[1][2][3][4]. The codes achieved a frame error rate as low as 10⁻⁴ for systems with hundreds of thousands of qubits, with decoding complexity that scales proportionally to the number of physical qubits—addressing a major barrier to practical quantum computing[1][2].

Traditional quantum error-correction methods hit an accuracy ceiling far below theoretical limits, requiring heavy computation that made large-scale systems impractical[1][2]. Kasai and Master's student Daiki Komoto constructed low-density parity-check codes defined over non-binary finite fields that handle both bit-flip and phase-flip errors simultaneously[3][5]. "Our quantum error-correcting code has a greater than 1/2 code rate, targeting hundreds of thousands of logical qubits," Kasai said[3][4]. The breakthrough could enable quantum computers to scale to millions of logical qubits, potentially advancing drug discovery, cryptography and climate prediction[1][6].

items.title: One in five solar panels degrades twice as fast as expected, UNSW study finds

featured_image.name: Shedding Light on Solar Panel Degradation - Exponent

items.description:
Researchers at the University of New South Wales have uncovered a troubling pattern in solar panel performance, finding that approximately 20% of panels examined degrade much more rapidly than industry expectations, potentially lasting only half their anticipated 25-year lifespan.

The study, published in IEEE and released January 5, analyzed data from nearly 11,000 photovoltaic systems worldwide to investigate what scientists call the "long tail" problem—where a subset of panels fails far more quickly than the average degradation rate[1][2][3].

"Most solar systems are designed to last around 25 years, based on their warranty period," said Yang Tang, a PhD student at UNSW's School of Photovoltaic and Renewable Energy Engineering and co-author of the paper[1][3][4]. "For the entire dataset, we observed that system performance typically declines by around 0.9% per year. However, at least one in five systems degrade at least 1.5 times faster than this typical rate, and roughly one in 12 degrade twice as fast."

For operators of solar farms where hundreds of thousands of panels are installed, the findings represent a hidden financial risk that challenges the economic models underpinning the industry's growth[1][2][3].

items.title: Calls for a royal commission into Bondi an untenable political distraction
items.description: Whether or not Anthony Albanese believes a federal royal commission is necessary, or even the best use of resources, is now politically irrelevant.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
